prompt:
Show all your work. Indicate clearly the methods you use, because you will be scored on the correctness of your methods as well as on the accuracy and completeness of your results and explanations.

The following scatterplot shows the number of wins and the attendance per game for 30 baseball teams in 2017. Also shown are the least-squares regression line and computer output.

(a) Interpret the slope of the least-squares regression line in context.

(b) Explain why it is not reasonable to use the least-squares regression model to predict attendance per game for 0 wins.

(c) What is the value of the correlation coefficient for the sample?

(d) If the point representing 64 wins and attendance of 40,786 people per game is removed from the set of data and a new regression analysis is conducted, how would the following be impacted? Explain your reasoning.
(i) The slope of the least-squares line:
(ii) The correlation coefficient:

attachments.description: Scatterplot showing relationship between number of wins and attendance per game for 30 baseball teams in 2017, with least-squares regression line and computer output table

parts.description: Interpret the slope of the least-squares regression line in context.
parts.response: For each additional win, the predicted attendance per game increases by 235 people.
calculations: Interpretation: For each one-unit increase in wins, attendance per game increases by 235 people on average

parts.description: Explain why it is not reasonable to use the least-squares regression model to predict attendance per game for 0 wins.
parts.response: It is not reasonable to predict the value of attendance per game when the number of wins is equal to 0. The number of wins in the data set only includes values from 64 to 104, so we cannot be confident that the linear model is a good predictor of attendance per game if we were to extrapolate outside of this interval, including at \(x = 0\).
calculations: Predicting at 0 wins would be extrapolation beyond the data range
Cannot assume linear relationship holds outside observed range

parts.description: What is the value of the correlation coefficient for the sample?
The slope of the least-squares line:
parts.response: If the point (64, 40,786) were removed, the slope of the new least-squares regression line would be greater. Because the point is to the left of \(\bar{x}\) and above the least-squares regression line, the slope of the least-squares regression with the point included is less steep (closer to 0). Because the slope of the regression line changes substantially, the point (64, 40,786) is an influential point.

If the point (64, 40,786) were removed, the correlation of the new least-squares regression line would be greater (closer to 1). Because this point is outside the linear pattern of the other data points, the correlation of the least-squares regression with the point included is less (closer to 0) than that of the new least-squares regression line.

criteria: The response correctly identifies the numerical value of the slope from the computer output.
The response interprets the slope as the change in attendance per game for each additional win, in context.
The interpretation of slope includes nondeterministic language (e.g., 'predicted attendance per game').
rubric.scoringNotes: Essentially correct (E) if the response includes all three components. Partially correct (P) if the response includes two of the three components. Incorrect (I) if the response does not meet the criteria for E or P.

criteria: The response states that the x values used to create the model do not include \(x = 0\).
The response provides numerical evidence that the x values used to create the model do not include 0 (e.g., the x values go from about 64 wins to about 104 wins).
The response uses at least one of the variable names (number of wins, attendance per game).
The response has the correct value of \(r = 0.351\) and includes supporting work.
rubric.scoringNotes: Partially correct (P) if the response has the correct value of \(r = 0.351\) with no supporting work, OR states that \(r = Â±0.351\) with supporting work, OR incorrectly uses the value of adjusted \(r^2\) to get \(r = 0.303\) with supporting work.

criteria: In part (d-i), the response states that removing the identified point would cause the slope to be steeper.
In part (d-i), the response includes an explanation based on the location of the identified point relative to the other points.
In part (d-ii), the response states that removing the identified point would cause the correlation coefficient to be greater (closer to 1) or stronger.
In part (d-ii), the response includes an explanation based on the location of the identified point relative to the other points.

reasoning: This question assesses students' ability to interpret regression output, understand the limitations of extrapolation, calculate correlation from R-squared, and analyze the influence of specific data points on regression statistics. The key concepts include slope interpretation with nondeterministic language, recognizing when extrapolation is inappropriate, the relationship between correlation and R-squared, and understanding how outliers and influential points affect regression analysis.

prompt:
The following scatterplot shows two variables, \(x\) and \(y\), along with a least-squares model.

Which of the following is a high leverage point with respect to the regression?

attachments.description: Scatterplot showing x and y variables with a least-squares regression line, with one point at (80, 70) separated from the main cluster

reasoning: A high leverage point is one that has a substantially larger or smaller x-value than the other observations. The x-value of 80 is substantially larger than the other x-values that occur between 5 and 40. High leverage points are identified by their extreme position along the x-axis (explanatory variable), regardless of their y-value.

prompt: An exponential relationship exists between the explanatory variable \(x\) and the response variable \(y\) in a set of data. The common logarithm of each \(y\) value of the response variable is taken, and the least-squares regression line has an equation of \(\log(\hat{y}) = 7.3 - 1.5x\). Which of the following is closest to the predicted value of the response variable for \(x = 4.8\)?
reasoning: Substituting \(x = 4.8\) into the equation gives \(\log(\hat{y}) = 7.3 - 1.5(4.8) = 7.3 - 7.2 = 0.1\). To solve for \(\hat{y}\), raise 10 to the power of 0.1 to get \(\hat{y} = 10^{0.1} = 1.26\). This demonstrates the process of back-transforming from the logarithmic scale to the original scale when working with exponential relationships.

prompt:
In a study to determine whether miles driven is a good predictor of trade-in value, 11 cars of the same age, make, model, and condition were randomly selected. The following scatterplot shows trade-in value and mileage for those cars. Five of the points are labeled A, B, C, D, and E, respectively.

Which of the five labeled points is the most influential with respect to a regression of trade-in value versus miles driven?

attachments.description: Scatterplot showing trade-in value versus miles driven for 11 cars, with five points labeled A through E

reasoning: Point E does not follow the trend with respect to the other data and is probably an outlier. The value of the car is much higher than other cars with similar miles driven. An influential point is one that, when removed, would substantially change the regression line. Point E has both high leverage (extreme x-value) and is an outlier (doesn't follow the pattern), making it the most influential point.

prompt: Data were collected on two variables, \(x\) and \(y\), to create a model to predict \(y\) from \(x\). A scatterplot of the collected data revealed a curved pattern with a possible cubic relationship (\(y = ax^3\), where \(a\) is a constant) between the variables. Which of the following transformations would be most appropriate for creating linearity between the variables?

choices.value: Taking the cube root of both \(y\) and \(x\)
Taking the log of both \(y\) and \(x\)

reasoning: Variables related by a power relationship, such as \(y = ax^3\), are best transformed by taking the log of both variables. When we take \(\log(y) = \log(a) + 3\log(x)\), we get a linear relationship between \(\log(y)\) and \(\log(x)\) with slope 3 and intercept \(\log(a)\). This log-log transformation is the standard approach for linearizing power relationships.

prompt:
The relationship between carbon dioxide emissions and fuel efficiency of a certain car can be modeled by the least-squares regression equation \(\ln(\hat{y}) = 7 - 0.045x\), where \(x\) represents the fuel efficiency, in miles per gallon, and \(\hat{y}\) represents the predicted carbon dioxide emissions, in grams per mile.

Which of the following is closest to the predicted carbon dioxide emissions, in grams per mile, for a car of this type with a fuel efficiency of 20 miles per gallon?
reasoning: When 20 is substituted for \(x\), the resulting value on the right side of the equation is \(\ln(\hat{y}) = 7 - 0.045(20) = 7 - 0.9 = 6.1\). The value of approximately 446 results from raising \(e\) to the power of 6.1, i.e., \(\hat{y} = e^{6.1} \approx 446\). This demonstrates back-transformation from the natural logarithm scale to the original scale.

prompt:
Which of the following statements about a least-squares regression analysis is true?

I. A point with a large residual is an outlier.
II. A point with high leverage has a \(y\)-value that is not consistent with the other \(y\)-values in the set.
III. The removal of an influential point from a data set could change the value of the correlation coefficient.
reasoning: Statement I and III are both true. A point with a large residual is an outlier and an influential point is one for which its removal from the set can have a substantial effect on the correlation. Statement II is false because a point with high leverage has an \(x\)-value (not \(y\)-value) that is not consistent with the other \(x\)-values in the set. High leverage is determined by extreme values of the explanatory variable.
